RUCTIONjjjRAMME,nounc em en t,gardingCruiser?pe.pjfrvi ou sinference:satinet 55'j) Con-conclusion 3 .9 a The Cabinet had before them the following documents:A Memorandum by the First Lord of theAdmiralty (Paper CP.-390 (28)) urging that the only question before the cabinet is whether or not it can now be announcedthat the two Cruisers of the 1928 Prpgrammeare to be of 10,000 tons displacement;stating that the Admiralty hold the strongest opinion that, these two Cruisersshould be built now, and that if theGovernment wishes to preserve our equality with the United States of America in 8-inchgun Cruisers beyond 1932, three more oughtto be built in 1929; but that if theGovernment are prepared to accept theposition at the end of 1932 of 178-inch Cruisers to 18 of the UnitedStates of America, the Admiralty will be willing to lay down three 6-inch gunCruisers in 1929 which will be requiredfor Fleet work, and that if it is insisted on they are ready to announce this now.In the concluding portion of his MemorandumMr Bridgeman drew attention to the seriousblow to unemployment, a blow not confined to the Dockyards, which would result fromdropping the Cruisers:A Memorandum by the Chancellor of theExchequer (Paper CP.-394 (28)) referring to a statement which Mr Gibson, the Headof the United States Delegation at the geneva Naval Conference, is said to havehad authority to make, namely, that theUnited States did not intend to buildmore 8-inch gun Cruisers than Great Britain:quoting a statement by the First Sea Lorda year"ago that the four HAWKINS ClassCruisers should count as the equals oftwo Japan-se 8-inch FURUTAKAS, whichwould accordingly add two to the figuresof our 8-inch Cruisers; urging, therefore,that neither parity with the United Statesnor the 5:3 ratio with Japan, and still less British nar."al safety, is endangeredby dropping the two Cruisers from thisyear's programme; quoting statements bythe Prime Minister and Lord Cushendun inregard to the effect of the Kellogg Pacton Naval Disarmament; urging that to drop the Cruisers would have a good effect-on Anglo-American relations, on british public opinion, and on achieving areduction of the Estimates of theFighting Services to 110,000,000 for1929; and commenting, as regardsunemployment, that Dockyards must depend upon policy, and not policy on Dockyards.In the course of the discussion it transpired thatthe First Lord of the Admiralty, in the calculationsin C.P.-390 (28)) had allowed for the four HAWKINSClass Cruisers being counted as the equals of two Japanese 8-inch FURUmAKAS . It also transpired that the First Lord o^ the Admiralty was certainthat Mr Gibson had not made the statement attributed to him at Geneva, and that th0 suggestion that hehad done so had been made by an American officialonly in a verbal and unofficial statement.A very long discussion took place, in the courseo^ which the First Lord of the Admiralty and theChancellor of the Exchequer developed theirrespective views at considerable length.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairsexamined the effect of the Chancellor of theExchequer's proposals on Anglo-American relations and reported that the view of his advisers in theForeign Office was that the effect would be favour-able both on Anglo-American relations and probably also on the Cruiser Programme to be adopted in theUnited States of America.The great majority of the Cabinet, however,shared the Prime Minister's view that to make a sudden, change in a programme which had been drawnup and approved by Parliament and the money votedearlier in the year, at the precise moment whenthe Senate of the United States of America is about to consider the American programme of constructionmight be regarded, in the absence of any ov er-riding considerations, as a calculated politicalmanoeuvre on our part with the object of in flu en c-ing the situation in America, and that consequently it might have the very opposite effect that we desired . Soire members of the Cabinet who held this viewconsidered that the programme should be proceeded with uninfluenced by the American situation,while others urged that a final decision shouldbe delayed until after the Parliamentary Recess,when the political situation in America inregard to the Kellogg Pact and the Naval Pro-gramme should have cleared up. This aspect of the question was adjourned to a Meeting tobe held later in the day.Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,December 19, 1928.
